name: Barry Bonds
reason: Barry Bonds 2004 season is not only the best MVP season on this list, but the best season of all time. Bonds put up an absurd 0.362/0.609/0.812 slashline and totaled one-hundred and twenty intentional walks, the most all time for one season. Bonds walked so much, that if he had played this season without a bat or the ability to swing at a pitch, he still would have got on base 37 percent of the time. Additionally, he slugged 45 homeruns along with 27 doubles, good enough for a 0.812 SLG percentage... no other player on this list besides Bonds himself had a SLG percentage over .700 in their respective seasons. You can debate all you want if Barry should be in the Hall of Fame and whether or not his statistics have an asterisk by them, but there is no debating that this level of dominance had never and will never be reproduced ever again.

name: Barry Bonds
reason: Bonds 2002 season is a very close second to his 2004 season but comes in second due to a slightly lower OPS, walk rate, SLG percentage, OBP percentage, and slightly higher strike out rate. Regardless, his 244 WRC+ and 12.7 fWAR are such insane stats that they will never be replicated again. Bonds not only dominated but was also clutch while he finished with a 10.51 WPA. Choosing between Bonds 2002 and 2004 seasons and which was more impressive was the hardest decision for me on this list, which is a testament to Bond’s dominance as no one else came close to the stats he put up in these two years.

name: Barry Bonds
reason: 73 homeruns. 2001 Barry Bonds not only was the MVP and put up an OPS .200 points higher than the 2nd place finisher, but he also set the all-time single season home-run record of 73 homers, a feat that will likely never be touched again for decades. The reason his 2001 season is 3rd on the list? He somehow managed to put a higher OPS, walk rate, fWAR, and WRC+ in seasons above, which is crazy to think he had statistically better seasons than the one he hit 73 bombs in.

name: Barry Bonds
reason: For Barry Bond’s to hit a .341/.529/.749 slash line in his “worst” MVP season on this list is absurd and a testament to how ridiculous his streak of four straight MVP seasons from 2001-2004 was. Once again, Bonds put up stats that are hard to fathom: a 212 WRC+, 10.2 fWAR, and a 26.9 percent walk rate, among other things. Bonds holds the top four spots on this list for good reason: he simply put up seasons that statistically were among the greatest of all time.

name: Albert Pujols
reason: Albert Pujols, who at the time of me typing this is sitting at 693 homeruns and chasing 700 in the year 2022, finds his 2008 MVP season fifth on my list. Pujols 184 WRC+ and 1.115 OPS are the highlights of his stats, but there were simply no flaws in his game in 2008. In addition to his high slugging, Pujols managed to walk twice as often as he struck out, contributing to a crazy high .462 OBP, and cementing himself at fifth place on my list.

name: Bryce Harper
reason: 2015 Bryce Harper was the Harper the baseball world was waiting for. Harper had a breakout season for the Nationals, posting a WRC+ just under 300 and an fWAR of 9.3! Even with a relatively high 20 percent strikeout rate, harper was able to walk at about the same rate which kept his OBP up and contributed to a league leading 1.109 OPS. The only odd caveat about Harper’s fantastic 2015 season is his negative WPA, which means he was either unlucky or not able to show up in big spots. Regardless, his monster 2015 season lands 6th on my list.

name: Miguel Cabrera
reason: Miguel Cabrera’s 2013 season can be summed up in two words: Triple Crown. The Detroit Tiger’s slugger not only dominated and won an MVP award, but he led the league in batting average, RBIs, and homeruns along the way. Accomplishing a feat that has yet to be repeated plus posting a 193 WRC+ and an 8.6 fWAR is good enough for a 7th place finish on my list.

name: Albert Pujols
reason: Coming in at 8th place is Pujols 2009 MVP season. Coming off a previous MVP award in 2008, Pujols showed no sign of content as he mashed a .327/.443/.658 slash line and a 189 OPS+. Similar to 2008, Pujols walked at almost twice the rate he struck out due to great plate discipline, and pitchers having to constantly pitch around him. Pujols dominance throughout the late 2000’s cemented his legacy as one of the best players of the decade and a future HOF.

name: Mookie Betts
reason: 2018 Mookie Betts was one of the most fun players to watch in recent years. The young star slugged a 1.078 OPS and posted an insane 10.6 fWAR, while leading the Red Sox to a world series championship. Although his time in Boston is done, his ability to perform at an MVP level and bring the city a championship in the 2018 season forever makes him a Red Sox legend.

name: Miguel Cabrera
reason: 2012 Miguel Cabrera can be described as a consistent, hitting machine with no flaws in his offensive game. The Tiger hit for power and a high average, resulting in an .999 OPS and a 166 WRC+. Cabrera’s 2012 MVP season was his first and set him up to have an even more impressive MVP season in 2013.

name: Giancarlo Stanton
reason: At the 37 spot is Miguel Tejada’s 2002 MVP season which propelled the famous “Moneyball” Oakland A’s to a 20-game win streak and a playoff berth. Unfortunately, a 20-game win streak is not because of one player, and Tejada’s 0.862 OPS and 128 WRC+ aren’t enough to move him any higher on this list. Although Tejada was able to hit .398, an underwhelming 5.3 percent walk rate resulted in a relatively low .354 OBP. To his credit, Tejada had a pretty high WPA and one could argue that he was a clutch hitter for an Oakland A’s team that defied all odds.

name: Ryan Howard
reason: Ryan Howard is often remembered as a power hitter who often swung for the fences but in 2006 Howard showed the versatility in his game slashing a .313/.425/.659 slash line. Good for a 1.084 OPS and a 162 WRC+, Howard dominated with both his power and ability to get on base. What is even crazier is that Howard put up these stats while striking out 1 in every 4 at bats!

name: Vladimir Guerrero
reason: It is crazy that I am more familiar with Vladimir Guerrero’s son rather than himself, but I see that as a testament to the talent and skills Vlad was able to hand down to jr. Guerrero’s 2004 season was his best; He slugged a 1.024 OPS and posted a 157 OPS+. Famously known as a hitter who could hit just about anything (even pitches that first hit the ground), Guerrero showed that to be true as he got on bade as a 42 percent clip.

name: Jose Altuve
reason: Jose Altuve’s 2017 season is unfortunately very controversial because a) the Astros were caught cheating, using technology to relay signs, and b) Aaron Judge got robbed of the MVP award. Regardless, Altuve put up solid stats highlighted by his .346 BA and 160 WRC+. This type of power is rarely seen from a second baseman, but his accomplishment will always be overshadowed by the controversies that surrounded it.

name: Alex Rodriguez
reason: Alex Rodriguez’s 2003 season with the Texas Rangers let the league know he was going to be an offensive force for years to come. The young stud put up an 9.2 fWAR and posted an OPS just shy of 1.000. While it may not have been one of his most impressive seasons, A-rod was just getting started and used this season to catapult him to another level in years following.

name: Andrew McCutchen
reason: Like Donaldson, McCutchen’s MVP season had solid production all around, but no crazy numbers to move it up the list any higher than 32. McCutchen slugged an impressive .912 OPS, which was boosted by a .404 OBP, along with a fWAR of 8.1. The highlight of McCutchen’s stat line is his 156 WRC+ and 157 OPS+, but a relatively low .508 slugging percentage holds him back from being put any higher on this list.

name: Josh Donaldson
reason: Josh Donaldson’s 2015 MVP season can be highlighted by a 154 WRC+ and an 8.7 fWAR. Donaldson slugged 41 homeruns and posted a 6.1 WPA en route to leading the low payroll A’s to the playoffs. Donaldson’s game is very solid overall and this season consisted of impressive production in every category, but nothing too special compared to other MVP seasons on this list, thus it comes in at 33.

name: Kris Bryant
reason: Kris Bryant’s lone MVP season comes in at 34 on my list. Bryant slugged an 0.939 OPS with a career high 39 homeruns and led a Cubs team to a 108-year drought ending world series championship. Bryant’s main criticism can be directed towards his 22 percent strikeout rate, and relatively low .385 OBP, but Bryant’s power was able to add value and offset where his plate discipline lacked. Since 2016, Bryant has not been able to replicate another MVP type season, but he will forever be a legend to Cubs fans and remembered for the things he did to bring the city of Chicago a championship.

name: Justin Morneau
reason: Justin Morneau’s 2006 season is characterized by a career high .934 OPS and 140 OPS+ (Min. 100 games). The first baseman 34 homeruns and 37 doubles, good enough for a .559 SLG and a silver slugger award. The only downside to Morneau’s MVP season is a relatively low OBP and WAR. The 3.8 fWAR Morneau posted is the lowest out of all MVP seasons greater than 60 games, and that is why he shows up at 35 on our list.

name: Dustin Pedroia
reason: Dustin Pedroia’s 2008 MVP season can be best characterized by his hustle, hard-nosed style of play, but statistically, it was a relatively below average MVP season. Highlights of his season are his 6.4 fWAR and stellar defense, but a 0.869 OPS and 127 WRC+ put a halt to any considerations of moving this season up on the list. Pedroia was a key piece of the 2007 and 2013 Red Sox championship teams, often providing value in ways that doesn’t show up on the stat line, but for this list, his lack of power and on base percentage puts him at the number 36 spot.

name: Miguel Tejada
reason: At the 37 spot is Miguel Tejada’s 2002 MVP season which propelled the famous “Moneyball” Oakland A’s to a 20-game win streak and a playoff berth. Unfortunately, a 20-game win streak is not because of one player, and Tejada’s 0.862 OPS and 128 WRC+ aren’t enough to move him any higher on this list. Although Tejada was able to hit .398, an underwhelming 5.3 percent walk rate resulted in a relatively low .354 OBP. To his credit, Tejada had a pretty high WPA and one could argue that he was a clutch hitter for an Oakland A’s team that defied all odds.

name: Ichiro Suzuki
reason: This might get me some hate, but after looking through the numbers, Ichiro’s legendary rookie MVP season falls in at #38 in my rankings. Highlighted by a .350 BA and 242 hits, Suzuki’s season lacked power and horrid 4.1 percent walk rate tanked his OBP. This resulted in a 0.838 OPS, lowest on this list, and for that reason his season comes in at number 38 for me.

name: Jimmy Rollins
reason: Coming in at 39 is Jimmy Rollins' 2007 season, which I rank as the worst 162 game MVP season in the last 20 years. Rollins' .875 OPS and 119 WRC+ are all-star caliber numbers, but in most years, they are not much more than that. A gold glove and a 6.5 fWAR helped Rollins steal the MVP from Matt Holliday, who with a .405 OBP and a 1.012 OPS should have probably won the award.

name: Freddie Freeman
reason: For the same reason as Abreu, Freeman’s MVP season comes in second to last. Freeman had an impressive short season, coming away with a 1.102 OPS and a 186 WRC+, but ultimately it was a lack of total production that hurts Freeman’s case.  It would have been interesting to see what numbers Freddie would have put up in a regular 162 game season, but his .366 BABIP suggests once again that regression was probably coming.

name: Jose Abreu
reason: The 2020 season being shortened to only 60 games automatically puts Jose Abreu’s MVP season at the bottom of this list. A 0.317/0.370/0.617 slash line in a full season would move him much further up, but a 2.9 fWAR and only 19 homeruns isn’t enough production to put Abreu’s season any higher. Additionally, his .350 BABIP suggests that over the course of a full season Abreu would regress to a lower level of production.
